Loch Gelly
Like most places in the area, Loch Gelly's name has a Gaelic origin, meaning "Bright Lake".The Loch was famous in by-gone days, for the superior quality of its leeches, which were used by most of the doctors in Scotland in the 18th Century, for reducing fevers.
The Loch lies at the foot of the south east slopes of the town of Lochgelly. It covers an area of two and a half miles in circumference. On the north and south side it is fringed with woods. The eastern edge leads on to mixed farm land and the Western edge leads to moorland and rough grazing.
